ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed this course, most of the readings were very interesting and I was encountering some authors and scholars (ancient and modern) for the first time. I appreciated the seminar style of the class, but it might have been helpful to indicate which readings we would focus for each class. I have found in larger seminar courses like this one, some professors choose to include weekly writing assignments or reflections on the readings as a way to gauge how students are encountering the readings since some students participate more vocally while others do better in writing. This may be a way to increase participation or at least see what students think about the week's readings before the class discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone interseted learning about and problematizing ancient "rhetoric" and rhetorical methods in an interdisciplinary way. Though the bulk of the reading pertained to classics or New Testament, most of the issues discussed had much wider applicability.
